chapter.title: Advanced options
chapter.para: In this chapter, we will explain miscellaneous options and features that power users might want to use.

sect1.title: Using &app; in kiosk mode
sect1.para: Kiosk mode is useful when &app; is the only software that runs at startup. It contains a system tab with buttons for tasks such as upgrading the Debian or Ubuntu packages, and rebooting the computer.
To launch &app; in kiosk mode, use the "--kiosk" flag from a terminal. It is best used with the "--fullscreen" flag.

sect1.title: Activating the debug mode
sect1.para: &app; supports a wide variety of devices and libraries. The tradeoff for this greater flexibility is a greater number of potential pitfalls, which may be difficult to troubleshoot. To get more information about what is happening behind the scenes, you can launch &app; in debug mode. To do so, launch it from a terminal with the "--debug" flag. Here is how to do it in Ubuntu GNU/Linux:

sect1.title: Using Milhouse
sect1.para:
The milhouse command line application is a powerful tool with many options not implemented yet in the Scenic GUI. For more complex setups than what Scenic can currently support, we suggest you use lunch as a launching script. Look at some examples in
trunk/utils/. You should look at the manual page of both these tools to know more about them.
Here is a quick introduction to using milhouse, an application for audio-video streaming over RTP.

The milhouse application is a simple tool that can do a lot of things. For example, it can list the cameras and video capture devices found on your computer. It can also change video settings for a V4L2 (Video4Linux2) device, such as its video standard and its selected video input number. Milhouse also supports DV cameras and DC cameras, two kinds of cameras using ieee1394 (Firewire) to send their digital video signal to the computer. These two camera types are not yet supported by the &app; graphical user interface. This is one of the reasons why an advanced user might prefer to use milhouse instead of the &app; graphical user interface.

Above all, Milhouse is an audio-video streamer. Its main purpose is to transmit digital video and audio signals over the Internet. As a streamer, it can be used in one of two it modes: as a sender or a receiver. To choose, simply give it the command-line option "--receiver" or "--sender".

sect1.title: Using milhouse as a sender or a receiver
sect1.para: To create a streaming session with Milhouse, you must launch a sender and a receiver. You must give each of them the IP address of the other one. That is what the "--address" command line option is for.

If you want to stream audio, the sender is the one that captures the audio signal from its audio source. You must choose a value for its "--audiosource" option. If omitted, the default is "jackaudiosrc", for the JACK audio server. Another common value is "audiotestsrc", a test source that generates simple test tones.

If you want to stream video, you must specify a video source for the sender, using its "--videosource" option. A common value is "v4l2src", for a V4L2 source. In this case, you might want to specify a video device, such as "/dev/video0", using the "--videodevice" option. The default value for the "--videosource" is "videotestsrc", for test color bars.

On the receiver's side, you must choose an output for the audio - the "--audiosink" argument - and specify the audio and video codecs, like for the sender (or use the defaults listed in milhouse --help).
We will create a milhouse sender and receiver on two separate computers.

sect1.title: Launch the receivers
sect1.para: Here is a short explanation on how to start the milhouse receivers to receive audio and video streams.
Set the local_machine display
Run the program on the local machine with the following parameters:

para.userinput: milhouse --receiver --address remote_ip_address --videosink xvimagesink --videocodec mpeg4 --videoport 10030 --audiosink jackaudiosink --audiocodec raw --audioport 10000 --numchannels 2

sect1.para: Set the remote_machine display
Execute this command on the remote machine with the following parameters:

para.userinput: milhouse --receiver --address local_ip_address --videosink xvimagesink --videocodec mpeg4 --videoport 10030 --audiosink jackaudiosink --audiocodec raw --audioport 10000 --numchannels 2

sect1.title: Launch the senders
sect1.para: The next step is to launch the milhouse sender processes. of course, that should be on a different computer.
Execute this command on the local machine with the following parameters:

para.userinput: milhouse --sender --address remote_ip_address --videocodec mpeg4 --videoport 10030 --videosource v4l2src --audiosource jackaudiosrc --audiocodec raw -c 2 --audioport 10000

sect1.para: Execute this command on the remote machine with the following parameters:

para.userinput: milhouse --sender --address local_ip_address --videocodec mpeg4 --videoport 10030 --videosource v4l2src --audiosource jackaudiosrc --audiocodec raw -c 2 --audioport 10000

sect1.para: A video window displaying the live video stream should appear on one of your designated screens. It is movable by holding down the -alt- key and dragging the window. Pressing 'f' or escape will toggle fullscreen mode.
You should also see the audio connections appear in qjackctl. The outputs are now routable to your speakers or other applications.
You should now have video and audio input fully working on both sides.
To stop milhouse type control-c in the terminal from which it was started or type control-q in the video window.

sect1.title: Multicast
sect1.para:
The milhouse command can also be used in multicast scenarios. All the same options apply as before, only two things need changing:
Both the sender (who will stream audio and/or video to multiple receivers) and each of the receivers need to specify the --multicast-interface argument, which specifies which network interface to use. A multicast address must be used for the --address argument, preferably in the range 239.0.0.0/8, which is intended for private or locally administered multicast domains (see RFC 2365).
A simple example of a multicast setup:
Sender:
milhouse -s --videoport 10000 --audioport 11000 --address 239.0.0.0 --multicast-interface eth0
Receivers:
milhouse -r --videoport 10000 --audioport 11000 --address 239.0.0.0 --multicast-interface eth0
